accordion-elements.title: Daily Schedule
accordion-elements.content:
• Shops and restaurants often close at midday (around 12–2pm)
  • Many shops and services are closed on Sundays
  • Mealtimes are later than in some countries — dinner typically starts after 7:30pm

accordion-elements.title: Money and Shopping
accordion-elements.content:
• France uses the Euro (€)
  • Contactless cards are widely accepted, but some places still prefer cash
  • Sales only happen twice a year (winter and summer) — “Les Soldes”
  • Bring your own bag — plastic bags often cost extra or aren’t provided
  • It’s normal to weigh your own produce at supermarkets using a machine

accordion-elements.title: Public Facilities
accordion-elements.content:
• Public toilets may require payment or have odd opening times
  • Tourist information centres are helpful for local advice, free maps and event details
  • Tap water is safe to drink — look for free water fountains in public spaces
  • Libraries often provide free Wi-Fi and quiet spaces to relax

accordion-elements.title: Health and Emergencies
accordion-elements.content:
• Pharmacies are marked with a green cross
  • There is always an emergency pharmacy open in each area, even on Sundays
  • You can call 112 for emergencies across the EU

accordion-elements.title: Culture and Social Norms
accordion-elements.content:
• It's customary to greet people with "Bonjour" (hello) or "Bonsoir" (good evening) when entering shops or restaurants
  • Tipping in cafés and restaurants is appreciated but not mandatory
  • France is officially secular — religious symbols are banned in public schools and institutions

accordion-elements.title: Dining Etiquette
accordion-elements.content:
• It's customary to keep your hands visible on the table, resting your wrists on the edge of your plate
  • Don't start eating until everyone at the table has been served
  • Many French people take their time over meals — it's a social event, not just about eating
  • It’s common to ask for "l'addition" (the bill) when you're ready to leave, as it won't be automatically brought to the table
